text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So probably one guy benefited and one guy has not. Uh, we’re about to do a third guy probably in the next few weeks. So, uh, but I think that trial I would probably want you to have at least been on one of the hormone drugs first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense? Patient: Um hum. How do you feel about it? text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: A mitosis means however the cell’s dividing. And you have like the very lowest mitotic rate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your gist basically it’s it’s a really dumb one; it doesn’t really know how to metastasize. So when you’ve got a cancer, you’d rather have a dumb one than a smart one. You had a really dumb gist tumor. But you’ve kind of got a smarter prostate cancer. So the gist tumor I think is extremely unlikely… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …to spread to a lymphnode although it is theoretically possible. But what is far more likely given the fact that you have a prostate cancer with you know high Gleason score and a PSA that is rising… Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum.

text: Family Member: and then a trial opens up does he just jump to the trial? Doctor: No. Oh, you got to date it, Sorry. Patient: Oh, I’m sorry. Doctor: I can’t even date it for you. It has to be you. Yeah. Um, Uh, If it’s working we don’t bail out, only if it’s not working, but we will have, you know, the trials are like a moving target so if there’s something that pops up and I think that you would benefit then yes, we would make that opportunity. So, I’m always aware of what’s up here which is why I pulled you guys back to say there’s nothing here that is anything other than chemo but now as we’re thinking about this I’ll know, you know, by this week, okay, that’s a lie because this is Thursday, Family Member: It’s Thursday Doctor: by next week, what two trials make sense based on you know what’s happening. You know, the hard part about those chemo trials is there is a group that only gets the chemo. I like that because everybody gets chemo. Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that.

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: So, a lot of times, they don’t let us move up. Sometimes they let us move up if the next guys have tolerated it well. Patient: And showed improvement or something like that? Doctor: Um, uh, yeah, that would be tough. And if they were benefiting and you weren’t, maybe higher dose – I don’t know what the rules are. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But, oftentimes they don’t let us increase the dose. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. But some protocols do. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So those are just nuance of that type of escalation. Uh. You --- it would be a window. So, it would be something that again if you’re trying to avoid chemotherapy, here’s something that I could try. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s, uh, uh, the third option of a trial, so, is chemotherapy plus vitamin C, a phase one study. The other study would be that we would have to check a blood test on you, uh, that if you came back as AR-V7 positive. And I’d have to see if we’ve already done that for you in the past.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
